head.citation-title: Attitude control strategies for an imaging cubesat
head.abstracts: Â© 2019 IEEE.This paper presents two different attitude control strategies for a fixed target-tracking remote sensing CubeSat. In particular, the observation mission profile requires the CubeSat to quickly reorient itself from its initial attitude to point an imager toward a fixed target area on the Earth's surface. It will then be required to slew in order to maintain a very accurate pointing of the same area for the several seconds required to the image acquisition. We first consider a classical proportional-derivative controller based on the feedback of quaternions, representative of the satellite attitude. Secondly, we implement an innovative optimal guidance based on a direct optimization method, the Inverse Dynamics in the Virtual Domain, and a nonlinear programming solver, the Sequential Gradient-Restoration Algorithm. The key advantage of such optimal guidance is the quick calculation of minimum-time reorientation maneuver.

In particular, the observation mission profile requires the CubeSat to quickly reorient itself from its initial attitude to point an imager toward a fixed target area on the Earth's surface. Secondly, we implement an innovative optimal guidance based on a direct optimization method, the Inverse Dynamics in the Virtual Domain, and a nonlinear programming solver, the Sequential Gradient-Restoration Algorithm.
